question_text: Based on the provided paper content, what specific experimental observations and mechanisms explain how wind speed and structural collapse increase firebrand production from building components, and what are the key fluid-mechanical and thermal processes involved?
standard_answer: Wind speed and structural collapse increase firebrand production through observable fluid-mechanical and thermal processes documented in experimental studies. Higher wind speeds generate stronger aerodynamic forces that mechanically fracture burning building components. As wind speed increases, the average mass and production rate of firebrands collected increase slowly at lower wind speeds then rapidly at higher wind speeds. Wind-induced pressure has the most effect on firebrand production, creating shear forces that tear off burning fragments from roof assemblies and wall components. Structurally, collapse events expose new surfaces to oxygen and heat, triggering rapid combustion and fragmentation. Experiments show increases in firebrand production were noted upon wall or roof collapse and start of flame ejections out of the structure through the roof or wall. During bench-scale building component experiments, higher wind speeds resulted in stronger wind forces capable of fracturing larger-thickness components, producing firebrands with greater mass. The thermal degradation of materials during combustion reduces their mechanical strength, making them more susceptible to wind-induced fracture. These processes combine maximum mechanical loading from wind forces with peak thermal degradation during structural failure events.
